Subject: Re: [neat] New Paper on Minimal Criterion Coevolution: A New Approach
 to Open-Ended Search
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=344770077; y=ofA6Jd1rORa_yI0QyRfhCRzUkNMgVrDk-862SQnP7_b7fR0Cmmwi
X-Yahoo-Profile: alienseedpod
From: Colin Green <colin.green1@...>

On 7 May 2017 at 05:52, kstanley@... [neat]
<neat@yahoogroups.com> wrote:
>
>
> Hi all, Jonathan Brant and I are pleased to announce our new GECCO Paper,
> "Minimal Criterion Coevolution: A New Approach to Open-Ended Search."
>

Nice work. I wonder how well traditional objective based NEAT would do
if we 'flipped' the selection and reproduction such that instead of
keeping some top N% elite, we dropped the lowest N% of the worst. (ok
technically that's the same process, i.e. e.g. 95% 'elitism' is the
same as culling the bottom 5%).

SharpNEAT also still has roulette wheel selection from the elite, and
I do sometimes wonder if that could go too, i.e. just select purely at
random from the remaining ('elite') genomes. All in the interest of
maintaining diversity and keeping the search broad and steadily moving
forward on multiple fronts. Speciation was always meant to fill that
role, but I've felt for some time that comparing phenotypes is more
akin to what nature does, that way we avoid the risk of speciating on
non-functional ANN structure.

It's interesting you observed good diversity with genotype based
speciation; I wonder if each ANN species ended up being paired up with
one maze species, and co-evolving in parallel with little regard for
the other species(?) My first instinct is to try and use the path
route diversity metric in something akin to fitness sharing, so you
get a good chance of surviving if you have a distinct/novel behaviour,
but a poor chance if lot's of other ANNs have the same strategy.  In
nature if you have the same strategy as lots of other's then you're
all competing for the same finite food source, but if you're unique
you have a food supply no-one else has access to.

Anyways it's nice to see more work in this general direction; I feel
like this is the right direction for neuro-evolution to be going right
now. Good luck at GECCO.

Colin
